title: Ethel (string quartet)
text:
Ethel is a <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a> based <a href="string%20quartet">string quartet</a> that was co-founded in 1998 by <a href="Ralph%20Farris">Ralph Farris</a>, <a href="viola">viola</a>; <a href="Dorothy%20Lawson">Dorothy Lawson</a>, <a href="cello">cello</a>; <a href="Todd%20Reynolds%20%28musician%29">Todd Reynolds</a>, <a href="violin">violin</a>; and <a href="Mary%20Rowell">Mary Rowell</a>, violin. Unlike most string quartets, ETHEL plays with <a href="instrument%20amplifier">amplification</a> and integrates <a href="improvisation">improvisation</a> into its performances. The group's current membership includes violinists Kip Jones and Corin Lee.
ETHEL performs <a href="Musical%20composition">original music</a> as well as works by notable <a href="contemporary%20classical%20music">contemporary</a> composers such as <a href="Julia%20Wolfe">Julia Wolfe</a>, <a href="John%20Zorn">John Zorn</a>, <a href="Don%20Byron">Don Byron</a>, <a href="Marcelo%20Zarvos">Marcelo Zarvos</a>, <a href="Pamela%20Z">Pamela Z</a>, <a href="Phil%20Kline">Phil Kline</a>, <a href="John%20King%20%28composer%29">John King</a> and many more. The group's 2004–2005 season culminated with a 45-city U.S. and European tour with the <a href="rock%20music">rock</a> musicians <a href="Joe%20Jackson%20%28musician%29">Joe Jackson</a> and <a href="Todd%20Rundgren">Todd Rundgren</a>, which included an appearance on "<a href="Late%20Night%20with%20Conan%20O%27Brien">Late Night with Conan O'Brien</a>". Their 2005–2006 season included the <a href="Cantaloupe%20Music">Cantaloupe Music</a> release of its second CD, "Light", performances at <a href="Brooklyn%20Academy%20of%20Music">BAM Next Wave Festival</a> with choreographer <a href="Wally%20Cardona">Wally Cardona</a> in New York, first-time performances in Miami (Florida), the <a href="Krannert%20Center%20for%20the%20Performing%20Arts">Krannert Center for the Performing Arts</a> in <a href="Champaign-Urbana%2C%20Illinois">Champaign-Urbana, Illinois</a>, performance at the new <a href="Experimental%20Media%20and%20Performing%20Arts%20Center">Experimental Media and Performing Arts Center</a> at the <a href="Rensselaer%20Polytechnic%20Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in <a href="Troy%2C%20New%20York">Troy, New York</a> as well as at the <a href="TED%20%28conference%29">TED</a> (Technology, Entertainment, Design) Conference, and a monthly residency at <a href="Joe%27s%20Pub">Joe's Pub</a>. In 2008 ETHEL worked with director <a href="Annie%20Dorsen">Annie Dorsen</a> to produce "ETHEL’S TruckStop™ : The Beginning" which was performed at BAM's Next Wave Festival. Months later, they offered another large scale performance, "Wait for Green", presented by <a href="Brookfield%20Place%20%28New%20York%20City%29">World Financial Center</a> in the <a href="Winter%20Garden%20Atrium">Winter Garden</a> with choreographer <a href="Annie-B%20Parson">Annie-B Parson</a>. ETHEL returned to the TED Conference in 2010 as the <a href="house%20band">house band</a>, performing with <a href="Thomas%20Dolby">Thomas Dolby</a>, <a href="David%20Byrne">David Byrne</a> and <a href="Andrew%20Bird">Andrew Bird</a>. They performed at <a href="Lincoln%20Center%20for%20the%20Performing%20Arts">Lincoln Center Out of Doors</a> in the summer of 2010, collaborating with <a href="Juana%20Molina">Juana Molina</a>, <a href="Dayna%20Kurtz">Dayna Kurtz</a>, <a href="Tom%20Verlaine">Tom Verlaine</a>, <a href="Patrick%20A.%20Derivaz">Patrick A. Derivaz</a>, <a href="Mike%20Viola">Mike Viola</a> and <a href="Adam%20Schlesinger">Adam Schlesinger</a>. In 2011, ETHEL was an <a href="artist%20in%20residence">artist in residence</a> at the <a href="Park%20Avenue%20Armory">Park Avenue Armory</a>.
Members of the group performed or recorded with <a href="Bang%20on%20a%20Can">Bang on a Can</a>, <a href="The%20Chamber%20Music%20Society%20of%20Lincoln%20Center">The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center</a>, the <a href="Orpheus%20Chamber%20Orchestra">Orpheus Chamber Orchestra</a>, the <a href="New%20York%20Chamber%20Symphony">New York Chamber Symphony</a>, CONTINUUM, <a href="Sheryl%20Crow">Sheryl Crow</a>, <a href="Roger%20Daltrey">Roger Daltrey</a>, and <a href="Yo-Yo%20Ma">Yo-Yo Ma</a>'s <a href="Silk%20Road%20Project">Silk Road Project</a>.
In 2002 the string quartet founded ETHEL's Foundation for the Arts, a <a href="nonprofit%20organization">nonprofit organization</a> with a mission to support contemporary concert music with <a href="Classical%20music%20written%20in%20collaboration">collaborative</a> projects, <a href="Commission%20%28art%29">commission</a> of new <a href="Work%20of%20art">works</a>, and <a href="Outreach">educational outreach</a>. In keeping with this mission, ETHEL has been the string quartet in residence since 2005 with the <a href="Native%20American%20Composers%20Apprenticeship%20Project">Native American Composers Apprenticeship Project</a> (NACAP), an affiliate program of the <a href="Grand%20Canyon%20Music%20Festival">Grand Canyon Music Festival</a>, which is dedicated to teaching <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native American</a> young people to compose <a href="Classical%20Music">concert music</a>. In 2011 NACAP was presented with a <a href="National%20Arts%20and%20Humanities%20Youth%20Program%20Award">National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Award</a> by First Lady <a href="Michelle%20Obama">Michelle Obama</a>.
ETHEL toured a program titled "Tell Me Something Good" with special guest Todd Rundgren in 2012. The program included <a href="Lou%20Harrison">Lou Harrison</a>'s "Quartet Set", <a href="Herbie%20Hancock">Herbie Hancock</a>'s "<a href="Watermelon%20Man%20%28composition%29">Watermelon Man</a>", a new commission, "Octet 1979", by <a href="Judd%20Greenstein">Judd Greenstein</a>, "Sunrise of the Planetary Dream Collector" by <a href="Terry%20Riley">Terry Riley</a>, "<a href="Spiegel%20im%20Spiegel">Spiegel im Spiegel</a>" by <a href="Arvo%20P%C3%A4rt">Arvo Pärt</a> and <a href="Led%20Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>'s "<a href="Kashmir%20%28song%29">Kashmir</a>", as well as an entire set of Todd Rundgren songs performed with Rundgren himself. ETHEL is the current resident ensemble at the <a href="Metropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art">Metropolitan Museum's</a> Balcony Bar Also this season, ETHEL will present a multimedia program, "ETHEL's Documerica", celebrating the 40th anniversary of the <a href="United%20States%20Environmental%20Protection%20Agency">Environmental Protection Agency's</a> "<a href="Documerica">Documerica</a>", launched in 1972. The program will feature new commissions from American composers; <a href="Jerod%20Impichchaachaaha%27%20Tate">Jerod Impichchaachaaha' Tate</a>, <a href="Ulysses%20Owens">Ulysses Owens</a> Jr., <a href="Kimo%20Williams">James "Kimo" Williams</a>, and <a href="Mary%20Ellen%20Childs">Mary Ellen Childs</a>, and will include a visual component designed by visual artist Deborah Johnson. "ETHEL's Documerica" will premier at the Park Avenue Armory as part of its "Under Construction" series. For a second consecutive year, the <a href="Jerome%20Hill">Jerome Foundation</a> has announced support of ETHEL's Foundation for the Arts "HomeBaked" program to commission new works from emerging New York City-based composers. ETHEL has announced that this season's composers will be Hannis Brown, Lainie Fefferman, <a href="Dan%20Friel%20%28musician%29">Dan Friel</a> and Ulysses Owens, Jr., with works premiering in Spring 2013. In 2014 <a href="Denison%20University">Denison University</a> announced that ETHEL will become their first ensemble in residence. In July 2016, Denison University announced that all four quartet members (Farris, Jones, Lawson and Lee) will receive honorary degrees, <a href="Doctor%20of%20Humane%20Letters">Doctor of Humane Letters</a>, honoris causa. The degrees were awarded during the college’s 176th Commencement exercises on Saturday, May 13, 2017.
